citations.narrative:
Sometime between the evening of 3/7/2024 and the morning of 3/8/2024, three foxes (Nora, Bolt, and Rip) escaped from
the twilight enclosure. The foxes dug an approximately 18 inches long tunnel that extended below the dig barrier on the
edge of the north wall of the enclosure and the north wall of the enclosure. After escaping the enclosure, the foxes then
dug a tunnel under the gate of the perimeter fence surrounding the twilight enclosure and escaped outside the perimeter
fence. Rip was seen on facility property the morning of 3/8/24. He was quickly captured and placed in a different
enclosure with a concrete base. Nora and Bolt were captured in different locations off facility property later in the day on
3/8/24 and placed in the alternate facility enclosure with Rip. All three foxes were captured in good health and without
injury.
A primary enclosure that is not designed and maintained to prevent escape of the animals contained within the enclosure
could lead to injury, harm, or loss of the escaped animals.
Primary enclosures for wild animals must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Sometime between the evening of 3/7/2024 and the morning of 3/8/2024, three foxes (Nora, Bolt, and Rip) escaped from 
the twilight enclosure. The foxes dug an approximately 18 inches long tunnel that extended below the dig barrier on the 
edge of the north wall of the enclosure and the north wall of the enclosure. After escaping the enclosure, the foxes then 
dug a tunnel under the gate of the perimeter fence surrounding the twilight enclosure and escaped outside the perimeter 
fence. Rip was seen on facility property the morning of 3/8/24. He was quickly captured and placed in a different 
enclosure with a concrete base. Nora and Bolt were captured in different locations off facility property later in the day on 
3/8/24 and placed in the alternate facility enclosure with Rip. All three foxes were captured in good health and without 
injury. 
 
A primary enclosure that is not designed and maintained to prevent escape of the animals contained within the enclosure 
could lead to injury, harm, or loss of the escaped animals. 
 
Primary enclosures for wild animals must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and contain the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
